Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES Collaborative proposal: How parents and their elementary school-age children solve science problems together: The role of gender and ethnicity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This project is investigating the role of gender and ethnicity in how parents (mothers and fathers) solve science problems with their young daughters and sons. Few studies examine the influence of parents, and the combined effects of gender and ethnicity on science problem solving and interest. The researchers are examining how parent gender, child gender, and ethnicity affect science attitudes, problem-solving approaches (as well as parental help and encouragement) and the discipline of science problem that they prefer. The theoretical framework includes Vygotsky's and Rogoff's sociocultural theories, Bronfenbrenner's ecological systems theory and Bem's gender schema theory. One hundred and fifty fourth-grade boys and girls and their parents (with a balance of Hispanic and non-Hispanic families) are observed while solving six life and physical science problems together. Qualitative data (from parent-child problem-solving tasks and a child attitude interview) and quantitative data (from parent-child problem-solving tasks, a child science assessment, and a parental questionnaire) are collected and analyzed using content analysis and inferential statistics.

Broader impacts: The research findings may assist researchers, parents and teachers to improve the participation and achievement of girls and Hispanic students in science disciplines. The dissemination plan includes presentations to professional audiences through conference presentations and publications, as well as brochures and websites for parents and teachers with advice about encouraging and assisting their students with science. Materials for parents will be made available to parent organizations, parenting magazines, libraries, and child care facilities. Brochures for teachers will be available to school districts, at local and national teacher conferences, and to pre-service teachers. This study is providing research training for both undergraduate and graduate students, and is being carried out by researchers in predominantly-undergraduate universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate parental influence, and potential gender and ethnicity differences, on elementary school-age children’s science problem solving behaviors, science interests and participation in out-of-school science activities.  Other researchers have noted that gender and ethnicity biases in science begin at an early age, when parental influences are strong.  We included over 150 fourth-grade boys and girls who participated with their parents (mothers and fathers).  Approximately half of the families were Hispanic and half were Non-Hispanic.  Additionally, we explored socioeconomic status (SES), by using parent education and family income as blocking variables, and only included findings for gender and ethnicity when they were not explained by SES.

When parents and children worked through science activities together, parents’ remarks focused on helping their children much more than encouraging them.  Mothers provided more help by stating an observation, compared to fathers.  Non-Hispanic girls and boys received more help in the form of questioning to prompt or aid in the understanding of individual activities.   Parents’ encouragement of their children was limited overall.  Non-Hispanic parents made more encouraging statements than Hispanic parents, but there was no difference in encouragement by child or parent gender.  Additionally, differences were noted in the time that parent-child dyads spent solving the science problems, and the amount of discussion (number of utterances).  Hispanic families spent more time working on the science activities overall, and girls and fathers spent more time on some individual activities.  Based on self-report, Hispanic girls enjoyed our problem-solving activities more than Non-Hispanic girls.  Language issues, involving whether or not the child and parent spoke the same language during the session, played a factor in the amount and type of discussion observed in Hispanic families.   

This project also examined early influences on the gender gap between men and women in physical versus life sciences in secondary school and beyond.  By the mid-elementary grades (4th grade in particular), some differences are beginning to emerge in out-of-school science activity participation.  For instance, Non-Hispanic families reported being more likely to play with building and electric circuit toys, and to visit science museums, as compared to Hispanic families.  In terms of child interest in physical science versus life science, there were few differences by child gender and ethnicity at this age.  Hispanic boys had a slight preference for some life science topics (i.e., animals), whereas Non-Hispanic boys had a slight preference for some physical science topics (i.e., space).  Mothers and fathers did not differ in their level of interest in physical science versus life science disciplines.

We observed several differences in science knowledge (on a science pre-assessment) by parent and child gender and ethnicity.  Fathers scored higher than mothers, but no differences were observed between boys and girls.  Additionally, Non-Hispanic parents and children scored higher than Hispanic parents and children.  More specifically, Non-Hispanic girls scored higher than Hispanic girls, but this was not the case for the boys in our study.

Parent experience in STEM fields did not affect participation in out-of-school science activities, parents’ stated values about science education, or their children’s interests in science activities.  As expected, parents with more STEM experience did score higher on the science knowledge assessment, however. 

These findings have implications for schools and family outreach programs.  All programs and materials should emphasize to parents that they do not have to be science experts in order to support their children’s interests in science.  Additionally, they may discuss the role of process praise and general encouragement in helping children to persist.  We suggest that more efforts can be made to reach out to Hispanic families, and these should emphasize the importance of including both daughters and sons in science activities.  Hispanic families (especially those with Hispanic girls) were very interested in the activities, as evidenced by the amount of time they spent and their self-reported interest, and yet they often have less opportunities and background knowledge to participate in certain types of out-of-school science activities (structured or casual at-home activities).  Furthermore, we recommend that programs offer materials in both English and Spanish when appropriate, and materials could include definitions and concept descriptions to help parents learn about the specialized science terms and concepts emphasized in the activity.  These materials would help parents who have less background knowledge on a topic to feel comfortable assisting their children.  

We have reached out to share our findings through a number of avenues.  We presented papers and posters at numerous national education and psychology research conferences and hosted a poster in Washington D.C. to share findings with our national representatives.  We also hosted outreach sessions with parents and school administrators from a number of our community partners.  We created a website and brochure for parents and teachers that highlight key findings from our project and suggest STEM activities and resources for families.
